steps.title: overview
steps.content:
Cotton is a cash crop grown throughout the world. Climatic changes such as rising temperatures, changes in the amount and timing of precipitation, increasing CO2 concentrations and pests/diseases will impact cotton growth during its developmental stages.

Nearly 75% of the world’s cotton relies on some form of irrigation. A water intensive crop, cotton requires adequate water to grow and prevent heat stress. It thrives in warm temperatures ranging from 32-42 degrees Celcius to grow. The crop also needs a dry period during boll formation that could be impacted by unexpected rains and flooding at this stage.

Stressors & shocks

Cotton production and temperature change

India

Increases in temperatures of up to 3°C are expected with climate change.

Increasing temperatures in northern India may reduce Himalayan glacial meltwater over time, a vital resource supplying the Indus river used for irrigation within India and Pakistan.

steps.title: insights
steps.subtitle: Cotton production & water availability
steps.content:
Soil moisture is essential to maximizing cotton yields. While crop models suggest yields may slightly decline in Northern India with climate change, slight increases in central and southern India will likely offset these losses. Declines in yield due to increasing temperatures are likely to be offset by increases from CO2 fertilization.

Interventions to retain soil moisture, like retaining crop residue, will increase the effectiveness of irrigation of the crop. The benefits of CO2 fertilization may be offset by increased competition from weeds. Reducing weed growth during the early stages of cotton development will improve yield success.
